job_title: Medical Records Technician in Seattle, WA
pros: Wonderful management Great work environment good work-life balance
cons: Pay increases Job building Ladder

review_title: Still a good place to work
pros: Powerful mission and vision -- to improve the health and wellness of the human community. Benefits are ok but free visits to the clinics are great if you want to see ND's or receive acupuncture or counseling support. Nice campuses and people who are committed to natural health. If that speaks to you, you've found a great place to be. Upcoming merger with smaller school could be a good thing as the university needs to grow and it will eventually expand the programs to the Portland market.
cons: Full benefit package could be improved. Cost of living increase every year, like in previous years. Pay adjusted to current best practices. Work/life balance is sometimes good, but everyone is being asked to take on more. But I hear this is true at a lot of companies so I don't think it's unique. There is opportunity in some departments for advancement as people leave, but not everywhere.

review_title: The pay and stress are not worth it
pros: the students are the best part of the job
cons: The cost of the education at the university, compared to what the pay their employees, even those that have been there for several years, just simply is not worth it. You can get paid way more and be asked to do way less at other universities and in other medical careers.

review_title: NO RESPECT FOR FACULTY BY ADMINISTRATION
pros: Faculty are committed to students and the mission. They work well together.
cons: President has no understanding or desire for any shared governance. No faculty raises in over 7 years but raises were given to administration. Faculty hours are cut at the whim of the president with no input from faculty. He consistently downgrades faculty and does not show respect for them ever. If you are looking for a faculty role that is supported by the administration this is NOT the place for you.

pros: Genuinely compassionate community and people
cons: Questionable leadership - President, Provost, and Board are out of touch with reality,. Favoritism in hiring without job postings. HR has overturned leaders 5 times in 5 years.

job_title: Core Faculty Member in Seattle, WA
pros: My colleagues and students at Bastyr are driven, kind, and dedicated. It would be difficult to find a more inspiring group of people.
cons: The university has struggled for years to achieve shared governance. This is at the heart of a lot of dissatisfaction.

pros: The students and numerous members of the staff.
cons: Senior administration has completely lost touch with the roots of the institution. They are more focused on current social trends and political “correctness” vs the mission of educating future leaders in healthcare.

pros: Staff and faculty are dedicated to the mission and try to serve patients and students
cons: The president has single handedly destroyed all faculty and staff morale. The university is poorly managed financially and senior leadership is ineffective, toxic and clueless. The entire finance department resigned under the current CFO. What does that say?

review_title: I would never work here again, and neither should you.
pros: An idyllic park like setting.
cons: 1.4 million dollars in the red, 2022-2023 Tone deaf leaders making poor financial decisions Clueless middle management No raises No employer contribution to retirement fund Multiple rounds of layoffs Low employee morale Lack of resources & support of employees Incompetent employees who have no fear of being fired

pros: None. Except for wonderful long term staff
cons: Going under due to bad management and board who have no clue

job_title: Medical Representative PSR in Seattle, WA
pros: Great place to work. Bosses and coworkers amazing!
cons: So much drama! Never ending call outs, too many people not wanting to actually work

pros: Solid mission and diversity statement Beautiful campus
cons: Lack of diverse leadership Pay is behind industry leaders

pros: Lovely campus, excellent food at cafeteria
cons: Need more interdepartmental collaboration and discussion

pros:
First, the Kenmore campus is stunning and there is a lot of rich history. The building used to be a monastery, and all of the offices used to be bedrooms.

HR was always great to deal with.

Lots of autonomy
cons:
The university, in my exerience, did not put money towards continuing education opportunities for staff. More money needs to be spent on DEI training for staff.

I felt very overworked at times here. Many departments are running on Skelton crews, and you can really feel it at times. This doesn't seem healthy or manageable long term.

The school was started 40ish years ago by people who were passionate about medicine, but not as knowledgeable about running a school.

job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Kenmore, WA
pros: Team members are nice. Environment is good.
cons: A lot of stuff to learn and read.

pros: Helping to support the mission of naturopathic medicine in a university environment.
cons: At the time, support of homegrown apps based on older technologies like VB and originally running on Access.

review_title: A great place to work except for the salary
pros: Student-centered focus, great colleagues, rewarding work
cons:
the salaries are below market value, even for academia
the school is having financial difficulties and there have been several rounds of layoffs

review_title: This place will suck the life out of you!
job_title: Senior Human Resources Generalist in Kenmore, WA
pros: I tried, I really really tried to find just one thing. If you have no experience at all, this is a great stepping stone. Your job after Bastyr, you will appreciate even more when you are given just the basics to do your job.
cons: The HR department is so overwhelmed with excel spreadsheets instead of the University investing in things such as an applicant tracker, eveything is still in the Stone Ages and you are expected to do the work of 3 people. I don't know anyone as an HR Professional that owuld be happy working here. If you are desperate for an income then this is the place to work, the only upside is that everyone that works there is on the misery train and understands. It's very difficult to get up and go everyday when employees are so misreable and there is no budget in HR to do anything about it. There have been no raises for faculty or staff in over 5 years.

pros: -Nice people to work with.
cons:
- No room for growth.
- No communication or being on the same page with academic departments.
- Health Insurance often does not work or just will not cover anything.
- Change of leadership is often.
- No consistency.

pros: Lots if sick time and vacation
cons: Work your a#$ off literally

pros: Flexible schedule, lots or autonomy
cons: pay is only reduction in your living expenses

pros: We attract students from around the world. Our research continues to lead the world in natural medicine research. We treat 45,000 patients a year in our Natural Health Clinics, some of whom are unable to get treated else where. We are proud to honor Bastyr's legacy of doing this work in natural medicine for nearly 40 years, and continue to work on integrating natural medicine into the healthcare system.
cons: I am disheartened and greatly disturbed to read negative reports about Bastyr University. It’s an amazing University full of heart, great passion, academic rigor, and is fully centered on students and faculty. People airing their personal agendas have been cruel and disrespectful to the President. This unsubstantiated negativity will affect students’ lives now and in the future. If you are unhappy and cannot take the rigor and accountability required, and put the pride and passion back into your work, then create unwarranted havoc somewhere else. The leader of Bastyr has been hired to move the University forward, which he has and will continue to achieve through his exceptional abilities to understand and support the needs of students, reconnect with alumni and listening to the needs of faculty. He is pouring his heart and soul into making the university sustainable, with the best curriculum, professors and opportunities for a good career after Bastyr. So try catching up and growing up. Your family members will read these blogs at some point in their lives, do you want to be the one to explain your lack of professionalism, respect and hurtful behavior? This insulting behavior is not mentoring or leaving behind a cherished legacy. Dr. Bastyr would be so ashamed if he were to read these negative blogs today!

pros: Wonderful students and beautiful campus
cons: Administrators are not sincere and lack empathy

pros: Passionate people, beautiful surroundings, great mission and vision
cons: You have to have good boundaries because most people work the job of at least 2 people

pros: Great hours and the pay is really good
cons: Occasionally dealing with impatient/rude customers.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Lake Stevens, WA
pros: MOST people that work at Bastyr are great people. There is a pretty generous vacation policy. The grounds are beautiful.
cons:
Bastyr has not invested money into technology, so most systems are barely working. The $50 mil budget is created in excel. The systems they do have on campus are old and inefficient. There is a lot of manual work that is time intensive, that could easily be fixed with new software.

Salaries are set across job classes, with no variation for performance or experience. It is next to impossible to get a raise besides the standard 2% COL raise each year. I think that causes some employees to do the bare minimum of work, since there is no incentive to do anything above or beyond.

job_title: Computer Programmer II in Kenmore, WA
pros: None. Toxic, Seattle freeze environment.
cons: Employees are overworked, inexperienced leaders

review_title: Love the work-life balance; would like increased training
pros: Just coming off of a 10-day winter break, followed by a 3-day weekend with MLK Day off – have never worked anywhere with this generous of a time off policy. My supervisor makes it easy to keep work-life balance, allows me to take advantage of employee massage benefits (on site) and Bastyr’s natural health clinic visits as a health benefit. On-site Parent Resource Center (daycare) was also super helpful when my child was younger. The whole foods cafeteria makes it easy to eat healthy lunch every day. Well, almost :)  I’ve been promoted once in my 3+ yrs working there.
cons: I would like to have more on-the-job training. To advance my career skills I have attended an outside conference, but could use more professional skill development. And while the grounds are beautiful (campus is in St Edwards park in Kenmore), it’s a brutal commute if you don’t live on the East side. No good public transit options.

pros: Students are extraordinary; leadership is committed to providing an extraordinary education; benefits are good; we hold fast to our vision and mission.  President Powell has built outstanding relationships with other institutions, donors, organizations, and Bastyr is the better for it.  The strategic plan initiated by the President, and created by the community at large is inspiring and folks are committed to seeing it to fruition.
cons: There are never enough staff or financial resources to do all we dream about doing. Our aspirations are lofty, and there's more work to be done to find other funding sources.

pros: At a time when many small universities are looking at budget cuts, campus closings, reductions in staffs, etc., Bastyr is going strong. Bastyr's staff and faculty are truly friendly and supportive - providing a very warm and welcoming environment. There are a number of activities to participate in from noontime exercise classes to discussion forums on current social issues. Plus the campus offers miles of trails to explore in the surrounding park.
cons: Not really a con but Bastyr is experiencing some "growing pains" as it works to improve processes and facilities so that it can continue on its path of being successful.

job_title: Administrative Assistant IV in Seattle, WA
pros: While working there, I've made many great friends. Faculties I've met were amazing people, and students I've met, some we've become friends. I've learnt a lot about naturopathic thru doctors and students.
cons:
Bastyr needs to hire a competent manager. While working there I was under a manager who manage the department remotely. We were at the clinic, and he was at campus. On top of that to support faculties and the demand of knowledge of audio video and computer they hired someone who has no previous knowledge of audio video or someone who at least knows how to use SKYPE. But instead they hire someone who has no knowledge of any of that. 
To make thing worse the manager kept believing whatever she said. Any lies that as long it made looks good, he believes her. Even though I worked there longer but he won't care.
NO incentive of working at Bastyr.

review_title: If you're thinking about working here, consider your options carefully.
pros:
I echo the sentiments of those who have posted to Glassdoor recently.  The situation at Bastyr has become progressively worse over the last year with Dr. Powell's presidency and actions from the board.  The last few years had been rough to start with - there are a number of managers and higher level employees who have been with the University for more than 15 years, and are resistant to change and completely out of touch with the realities of higher education this century.  Add in a new President who absolutely refuses to adjust to or adopt a very ingrained, developed culture, and you've got a recipe for disaster.  

Since this is technically the "pro" section of the review, I will say that there are still a few good employees and faculty members remaining at the institution.  If you're lucky enough to get offered a role on one of those teams, I'd encourage you to consider it but do so very carefully.  The culture is toxic right now, benefits and pay are poor, and there is no opportunity for professional development or advancement.  If you can still believe you can get something out of the situation knowing all of that, it might be worth a shot.  Just be sure you know what you're looking for, get in, get it, and get out.
cons:
Cons are numerous, and frankly too complicated for a quick review like this.  The other reviews posted are accurate - the culture has become toxic, and employees being ignored is frankly a best case scenario.  More commonly, those who speak up are bullied into silence by management, the board, and even human resources.  There is a facade of caring through an "open door" policy and community town hall events, but nothing comes of them, and they seem better at instilling more fear into the community than anything else.  As I mentioned before, benefits are terrible.  There is little respect for work/life balance, and it is an incredibly difficult environment for anyone with a family.  They don't provide any paid parental leave - a perfect example of them not practicing what they preach.  Some admin positions make a decent salary, but that's about it.  

Bastyr is significantly behind the times from a technology standpoint, and refuses to invest in any sort of infrastructure to support the growth they're demanding.  The human resources department and VP are the worst I've ever seen in an organization this size, and they have freely admitted to me that they do not believe it's their responsibility to be sensitive to employees' needs.  They fact that they haven't yet claimed their Glassdoor page or responded to any reviews should tell you something.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: I've been an employee for 4 years at the San Diego campus and have nothing but good things to say about the University.  The people really care about the students, and the students take excellent care of the patients we serve.  We've had two outstanding presidents and solid campus leadership.  Nicole Moreno is amazing, and I'm so glad that Dr. Powell brought her to Bastyr.
cons: We could always make more money.

pros: there are many good, faithful employees here working to support the school the best that they can.  Expansion of different programs in the last 10 years has been good plus the opening of the San Diego Campus. there are some good HR benefits for employees.
cons: Upper Administrative management seem to be disconnected now to what the work is.  Many employees are now over worked and underpaid .  Seems to be some lean years ahead.

pros: The people that work in the trenches day after day deserve the most credit. The doctors and staff are doing their best under challenging circumstances.
cons: Don't believe all of the "glowing" reviews that piled in at the end of July, especially those praising the university president. The fact that they are all five stars and look professionally written give me great pause. Those that do the grunt work every day know the real truth. If you are considering working here, I highly recommend reading all reviews going back a couple of years, and do more online research on Bastyr. Then you can make a more informed and balanced decision

pros: It makes me proud to work at a place that impacts so many lives. Bastyr is a leader and a game changer in health care, and is only growing. I’ve been here over 10 years, so I’ve enjoyed seeing so many students and patients come through and leave wiser and healthier. Gives me a sense of gratification. As an employee I’ve worked in different roles within the university over the yrs and had a chance to develop various different skills and growth. My fav perks are taking breaks in the herb gardens, eating lunch at the delicious/nutritios dining commons, and working with many of my friends. Also taking advantage of free acupuncture and other natural med appointments at the teaching clinic.
cons: Bastyr may be 38 years old in people years, but in institution years is much younger. If I had to guess its age, I’d place it in the adolescent years - which is an awkward stage - sometimes annoying to be around, and sometimes even a little painful to go through yourself. Yet necessary to mature into an adult. And still just that, a stage. Unfortunately, when you’re on the inside, you’re not always able to look from the outside in to notice what stage of growth you’re in in the moment. This makes it a challenging stage for some employees to move through. Because everyone has their own way of responding to or embracing change/growth.

pros: Great company culture.  Lots of fun events, free fitness classes, free treatment at the on-site clinic, inexpensive massages, conferences, educational movies, great cafeteria with amazing choices of organic and vegetarian dishes.  Loved the interaction with students and faculty members.  Learned a lot of new things regarding natural medicine alternatives.
cons: Somewhat low salaries, but the benefits and training opportunities compensate the salary part.  Parking is a bit difficult.  .

pros: Strongly promotes a work-life balance. Great benefits. Holidays off. Great schedule for having a family. Food quality (organic, local, sustainable, made from scratch) Promotes healthy lifestyle and is a positive environment for working in. Promotes diversity. Students are inspiring. School is large enough to be a stable career with long term incentives but small enough to feel like  your part of a family-style community.
cons: Some equipment and processes are a little behind the times.

review_title: Amazing Mission, Beautiful Place, Hard working people
job_title: Enrollment and Marketing in Kenmore, WA
pros: The campus is in a state park! Gorgeous. This is the only full University in the world that combine Health, Science and Nature and has 22 degree programs. A rich environment for people who care about the health and wellness industry/education.  Seems that problems have happened in the past, but these are on the way out from what I can tell...glad to be part of this cool group.  Changing my life!
cons: Kenmore is a little far from where I live, but I just get a podcast and drive on...

review_title: Interesting place to work in a beautiful park setting.
job_title: Mid Level Administration in Kenmore, WA
pros: Center of advancing wellness and blending naturopathic and eastern medicines to modern or western medicine.  Promotes healthy diet and lifestyle.  Most of the employees and all of the students are very interested in promoting and living well.  The garden and grounds are a very nice place to work.  The cafeteria provides well balanced options that are healthy, organic, and as locally sourced as possible.
cons: Small school with limited resources.  Training and advanced planning can be a bit dodgy on a case by case basis depending on the office and location.

review_title: Bastyr used to mean something good
pros: The students are amazing!  Their attention to environmental issues as well as their rigorous studying, to try to make the world a better place!
cons: The people actually running the university, do not even understand how it operates.  There are many details not being acknowledged as being important, that are  very important!  This applies to all departments!

pros: I still believe in the hard working faculty and staff that remain for the sake of the students and the medicine.
cons: New president is Megalomaniac. He fails to express empathy in any believable way, he disrespects employees daily, chews up and spits out hard working employees to advance his own self-serving goals, fires dedicated and successful employees without warning... He is putting Bastyr's excellent reputation at risk as he rips the still-beating heart out of this incredible place. The best of the best are quitting first and the goodbye parties (off campus) are happening nearly weekly.

pros: The only thing I can say that is positive is that there are still a few great employees here that are holding on waiting for the Board to realize what a mistake they made
cons: This used to be a fantastic place to work. Now it is a shell of its former self. The administration is a disaster, great people are leaving all the time, money is spent on garish library upgrades instead of quality people and the place is run my a megalomaniac. Run!

pros: The student and faculty dedication to the Bastyr mission & to natural healing are impressive. They are the heart and soul of Bastyr.
cons:
Bastyr continues to hemorrhage caring, dedicated, intelligent, hard-working employees - all sacrificed to the ego of the current president. For absolutely no good reason, "Mac" Powell is systematically dismantling vital departments at Bastyr - destroying livelihoods & lives in the process. Good people who have already given five, ten, fifteen, even twenty years of their lives to the Bastyr mission are being driven out & clueless cronies from Powell's past are being brought in, with predictably terrible results for the institution. If only the Board of Trustees were not blindly aiding and abetting him in this devastation.

The only thing that could possibly save Bastyr from these narcissists, psychopaths, corporate drones, cowards, bean counters & sycophants would be a complete rebellion by faculty & students. 

However, it may already be too late. Does the Bastyr community have the courage to fight back to save the institution? Is the mission worth fighting for? Or is everyone left who ever cared about Bastyr students and the Bastyr mission going to quietly tip-toe away like timid mice and allow the Bastyr vision to go dark?

review_title: Bad leadership in a once good place
pros:
When I began my time at Bastyr, I loved the amount of respect I received from my team and from the departments around the university.  I was treated by the majority of the staff as a specialist who was hired for good reason.  My ideas were listened to, they were debated, and many were implemented.  I felt like I was making a difference in the direction of the university.  I felt like part of a larger team of dedicated staff, faculty, and students.

On top of this, I received decent benefits and my work-life balance was respected.  I was working in the middle of St. Edwards Park and took advantage of the hiking trails almost every day.  Going to work was pleasant and I wanted to be there.

Even after moving on, I miss the environment.  I can’t disappear into the woods at lunch where I am now.  I don’t get to listen to movie and video game soundtracks getting recorded in the chapel while I work.
cons:
That is not to say that when I first got hired that everything was working well.  There are a few firmly entrenched staff members who are very resistant to change and who believe they know better how to do the jobs of their coworkers.  The university doesn’t give much support to their technological initiatives and they only survive by the skill of those that signed on due to their commitment to the university’s mission.  Also, being a small, non-profit university, the pay is not great.  But these were not the reasons I left.

Almost a year ago, the board hired a new president.  When he arrived, he created a plan to change the university which seemed bold, but was incredibly vague.  In his initial town hall meetings, he would answer questions is radically different ways based upon who was in the room.  He eliminated vacant positions that were not only necessary to the university on the whole, but were necessary to executing his initiatives.

He also made vague statements about what he wanted to see, but never when he wanted to see them or what strategy he was following in asking for them.  After six months, he began forcing people out because they could not meet his vague demands that had no timeline.  He did it by making the jobs harder than they should have been.  He did it by guaranteeing a certain amount of time to execute his goals, and then changing the deadline suddenly.  He did it by asking for people’s resignations.  He did all of this so that he could stand behind the statement that he never had, and never would, fire anybody.

And after he forced people out, he began micromanaging key departments with the assistance of his Chief of Staff.  Mine and my team’s input no longer mattered.  We no longer assisted in steering the university’s mission.  Our responsibilities were being farmed out to freelancers without our knowledge.  Projects showed up half formed with no strategy and we were given no time to clean them up.  We executed vague plans with large price tags.  We executed projects that we knew would fail.  And we were scared of what that failure meant.  So a lot of us have left.  And a lot more will be leaving soon.

pros: So many good people work here who still adhere to the original mission statement and are here for the students and for health care. The grounds are beautiful, the food is healthy, and the faculty teach to a high standard. What little is left of the old guard still cares.
cons:
Work conditions: Most are doing the work of 1-1/2 to 2 people. Pay is under the norm. There is no upward movement and not much lateral. Employees work areas are quiet enough to hear a pin drop - there is no laughter like before. Our friends are being fired, laid off, being made miserable enough to just quit. There aren’t even management thank yous or good byes, like they never existed. Many more are planning their exit to avoid that fate. 

Upper management is ineffective. IT and Marketing and many other departments are understaffed. IT is backlogged. “Leadership” is top heavy within a very small group. Serious staff and work balance issues are ignored by top management, so middle management work is difficult.

Many staff are on FMLA to avoid stress and health issues. Gossip is rampant. 

There are more firings each week, sudden and without notice. We wonder who is next. People often disappear an hour after you last saw them, blindsided and shown the door without thanks or goodbyes. 

A recent review states our founder would be ashamed of the complaints. That is true, but for a different reason. I think he would be ashamed of how previously valued employees are being treated.

review_title: Fails to reflect the principles upon which school is founded
pros:
Many of the staff, faculty and students are committed to the principles of holistic health (which includes social justice, compassion, respect, integrity)! 
Many passionate people (being worked into the ground).
cons:
I would tell people not to apply but since there is a current hiring freeze, that won't be necessary. I question the integrity of the most recent positive review, sincerely believing they were written by HR.

Morale is at an all time low that I have seen in over 10 years. While there have been "issues" between departments in the past, the focus continually returns to the mission - teaching, which include patient care. Now with all the cuts being made, quality of education on every level is being compromised, and the staff and faculty are unhappy and fearful of their jobs. This is impacting health and wellbeing, but the administration, and president, fail to understand this. One proposal (just a discussion point at this stage) for balancing the budget is for faculty to voluntarily donate a percentage of their pay back to the student scholarship fund (a very lofty and nobel request), however, we have not heard what concessions the administration are willing to make. This is the first time Bastyr is paying for the president's house and car, which might be one budget cut possible. Often the response is something about how "this is a standard practice in academia, yet supposedly we are in financial straights now. This may only amount to a small portion of the budget, but it would be a) a gesture and b) something. 

The president says he has an open door policy, which is intriguing, since he fails to demonstrate listening skills. His style is often combative and defensive of feedback. In public he declares how we should all "be kind," yet he is not. 

When people leave Bastyr, either quitting a job without another one lined up or for a job in a completely different sector, these individuals are often described as being uncomfortable with change. This is amusing since that seems to be the embodiment of change.  

All of this is impacting students and several prospective students who have declined attending due to all the turmoil being shared by currently enrolled students.

cons: Customer service is always 50/50 risk. You never know what type of person you will be dealing with. Generally speaking though with any job too, put out the respectful you wish to receive. Most everyone is very sweet coming the clinic.
